title: Truleigh Hill Walking Route

images.title: Simon Carey [CC BY-SA 2.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Truleigh Hill on a beautiful autumn day in 2008. Much of the northern escarpment is in this square though the actual peak and radio masts are in TQ2210. Taken from the footpath that links Small Dole to Fulking.

images.title: Simon Carey [CC BY-SA 2.0 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Radio Transmitting Station, Truleigh Hill. Originally the site of a radar station during the Second World War. Here viewed from the South Downs Way footpath.

images.title: Peter Holmes / Access road to Truleigh Hill
images.caption: Access road to the hill. Looking east towards the Youth Hostel at Tottington Barn

images.title: Ian Cunliffe / River Adur - view towards Truleigh Hill
images.caption: River Adur - view towards Truleigh Hill

images.title: Simon Carey / View from Beeding Hill
images.caption: View from Beeding Hill which lies just to the south west.

images.title: nick macneill / Freshcombe and Summersdene Farm, Truleigh Hill, West Sussex
images.caption: Freshcombe and Summersdene Farm

images.title: Simon Carey / South Downs Way
images.caption: South Downs Way bridleway to the south west of the hill.

images.title: Simon Carey / View from the South Downs Way
images.caption: View from the South Downs Way in late evening autumnal sunshine. Thundersbarrow Hill is in the distance.

description: This hill in West Sussex has a set of distinctive radio masts on the summit. You can park at a small parking area to the west of the hill and follow the South Downs Way past Beeding Hill to the top of Truleigh Hill. There's great views of the surrounding hills and countryside from the high points. You can turn it into a circular walk by following tracks across Bushy Bottom and then the Monarch's Way back to the car park. You could also start the walk from nearby Upper Beeding or Bramley Castle if you prefer. To extend your walk you can continue east along the South Downs Way to Edbarton Hill and then on to Devils Dyke. The beautiful V-Shaped Valley is a great place for walking and mountain biking. You can use the google street view link below to follow this part of the trail.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: You could also start the walk from the nearby village of Fulking if you prefer. Following the South Downs Way west from the village will take you along the Fulking Escarpment to the hill. The Shepherd and Dog pub in the village has a car park making it a good alternative start point. See the Fulking Circular Walk for more details. To continue your walking in the area see the South Downs Walks page.

display_address: Upper Beeding, Horsham, West Sussex, England, BN5 9XH, United Kingdom
